title: The GROUP BY Clause
learning_objectives: Group rows by one or more columns
Use HAVING to filter groups based on aggregate values
Understand the execution order of GROUP BY and HAVING

definition.concept_explanation: GROUP BY organizes rows with the same values into summary rows for aggregate calculations.

examples.title: Example for group-by
examples.explanation: See the practice problems for more examples.
examples.expected_output:
| id | name | email | age | city |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 1 | Alice | alice@email.com | 25 | Seattle |
| 2 | Bob | bob@email.com | 30 | Portland |
| 3 | Charlie | charlie@email.com | 22 | Seattle |

common_mistakes.title: Missing column in GROUP BY
common_mistakes.error_sql: SELECT city, age, COUNT(*) FROM users GROUP BY city;
common_mistakes.error_message: Error: column 'age' must appear in GROUP BY clause
common_mistakes.why_it_happens: When grouping, any non-aggregated column in SELECT must be in GROUP BY.
common_mistakes.fix_sql: SELECT city, age, COUNT(*) FROM users GROUP BY city, age;
common_mistakes.key_takeaway: Include all non-aggregated columns in GROUP BY

practice_challenge.description: Find cities that have more than 2 users, ordered by user count.
practice_challenge.hint: Use GROUP BY with HAVING and ORDER BY.
practice_challenge.solution:
SELECT city, COUNT(*) as user_count
FROM users
GROUP BY city
HAVING COUNT(*) > 2
ORDER BY user_count DESC;
practice_challenge.explanation: GROUP BY groups users by city, HAVING filters groups with more than 2 users, and ORDER BY sorts the results.
